awd_titl_txt: GEOPATHS-IMPACT: Geosciences Opportunities with Fossils, Rocks, &Water to Attract underRepresented Discoverers (GO FoRWARD)
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
Of all STEM fields, the geosciences student and workforce populations are the least racially and ethnically diverse. Increasing participation of underrepresented groups in the geosciences is not only a social imperative with inherent benefits to better society through more diverse perspectives in the workforce, but it is a necessity for the prospect of the geosciences discipline which has a predicted shortage of skilled scientists within the next decade.
The extremely low numbers of underrepresented students majoring in geosciences may be a reflection that the geosciences disciplines have barriers beyond other STEM fields. This project addresses some of those barriers through a pilot project at two partner institutions in Milwaukee, Wisconsin: an urban research university and a two-year technical college. Early career college students from underrepresented groups will be invited to participate in geosciences research opportunities, community development, and education about public- and private-sector jobs while receiving close mentoring from faculty and more advanced students. The primary goals of this program are twofold: 1) to increase the numbers of students from underrepresented minority groups selecting geosciences majors, and 2) to smooth a pathway for students from a two-year college to become geosciences majors at a neighboring 4 year institution.  

Part 2
GO FoRWARD (Geosciences Opportunities with Fossils, Rocks, & Water to Attract underRepresented Discoverers) is an initiative for underrepresented minority students in their first two years of college to explore geosciences research and career options. The two institutions working closely together are the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and Milwaukee Area Technical College. 
The paucity of underrepresented persons in the geosciences can be attributed to several barriers, including lack of exposure to the discipline; stereotype threat; and imposter syndrome. The aim of GO FoRWARD is to help mitigate these impediments via five proven strategies which are integrated throughout the project activities: 1) Early exposure to Geosciences; 2) Emphasis on employment; 3) Dynamic experiences; 4) Creating a sense of community; and 5) Strong mentorship.  Two additional strategies will be utilized to further facilitate the academic transition for students from MATC to a four-year institution: 1) targeted advising; and 2) smoothing educational pathways. 
Students will be invited to participate in an intensive summer geosciences research experience and follow-up research options throughout the academic year.  Career information and community building will be integrated throughout the program to address barriers.
Success for the GO FoRWARD pilot study will be determined by student participation at various stages of the project and documented participation of underrepresented minority student participants in additional geosciences courses and degree programs.  This pilot project will test whether strategies employed in other STEM fields can be modified and used to attract underrepresented learners to geosciences degree programs and careers.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
Of all STEM fields, the geosciences student and workforce populations are the least racially and ethnically diverse. The extremely low numbers of underrepresented students majoring in geosciences may be a reflection that the geosciences disciplines have barriers beyond other STEM fields including lack of exposure to geosciences at the high school level in many states, negative perceptions of geosciences career paths and stereotypes of geoscientists, and lack of family support for pursuing a geosciences career. The Geosciences Opportunities with Fossils, Rocks, &Water to Attract underRepresented Discoverers (GO FoRWARD) program at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee was designed to address some of those barriers. GO FoRWARD was designed as a 3 year program to invite students from historically excluded groups to participate in geosciences with the goal to improve recruitment and retention of students in Geosciences degree programs.  First and second year students from University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and Milwaukee Area Technical College from historically excluded racial and ethnic minority groups were primary participants in the program.  The highlight of the program was an annual one month paid summer geosciences experience for small cohorts of students who gained geosciences education, research experience, career information, personalized mentoring, community building, and discussions about the field. Current undergraduate and graduate students in Geosciences were invited to be peer-mentors to provide them with opportunities for professional growth. Throughout the academic year, members of summer cohorts were invited to stay engaged in geosciences by taking courses, conducting paid research, and participating in extra-curricular geosciences events. Due to Covid-pandemic restrictions, the three-year framework of the program was modified, so the program welcomed full cohorts of twelve to fifteen students in 2018 and 2019 and half-sized cohorts in 2021 and 2022.  In 2023, the program provided a less-extensive experience for students by providing several day-long fieldtrips to museums and interesting geologic field sites guided by peer mentors.

 

Thirty-eight students participated in the four summer cohorts and twenty-eight undergraduate and graduate geosciences students were hired as mentors.  Survey data from students who participated in the summer cohorts indicates that students overwhelmingly gained knowledge and improved perceptions of geosciences disciplines and careers due to their participation in the program. Of the students in the cohorts, 24% declared geosciences majors and an additional 24% declared related science majors.  Subsequently, 50% of the cohort students took geosciences courses after their participation in the cohorts.  29% of the cohort students participated in subsequent undergraduate research in geosciences.  26% of the cohort students participated in subsequent extracurricular geosciences activities.  Student mentors reported that they gained self-efficacy and found motivation to persist in their degree programs. During the GO FoRWARD program, demographics of students within the UWM Geosciences department became more diverse.  In comparison, the less expansive fieldtrip experiences in 2023 did not yield significant results. Although many students signed up for the fieldtrip experiences, a high percentage (60%) of registrants did not attend, and those who did attend were unlikely to engage with geosciences classes or research in subsequent semesters.  We conclude that a holistic and immersive approach to student recruitment like the one offered by the GO FoRWARD summer month long immersive program, although costly in both time and financial investment, is key to furthering recruitment of students from diverse backgrounds into Geosciences.  Furthermore, follow-up mentoring, research, and professional experiences are key to retaining students within Geosciences degree programs.

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2024
Modified by: Dyanna M Czeck
